Hi

Is there any explanation of why this nag mesage keeps popping up? There’s nothing on the help pages, nor can I find anythign on the forum.
The explanation underneath says “We’ll occasionally ask you to verify your PIN so that you remember it”.

This comes across as being rather patronising and nannying. I think these days most folks know how to remember important PINs and I never seen this at the ATM or store tills, so why this approach? There are much more respectful ways to educate users about security and the impact of forgetting PINs. What happens if I don’t verify it?

I want to recommend Signal to my contacts but this kind of thing means I struggle to justify it.

Does the desktop app nag too? It’s not appeared so far.

No, as far as I’m aware PIN reminders never appear on linked devices.

awaitlink:

PIN reminders never appear on linked devices.

Which makes sense, because you have to set up a primary device before you can use a linked device, and the primary device is going to be the one that requires entering your PIN. Linked devices don’t require entering your PIN to set up or any other reason, and you also cannot change your PIN from linked devices (at least with the Desktop app, not sure about iOS).

As I can’t remember the exact look right now of the PIN reminder…

  • Is there a button for more information to help people understanding what it is about?
  • And is there a button like “don’t ask me again”?

This would improve the usability a lot for people to turn it off without the need to look into the settings. Especially because many seem not to know about this option to turn it off and turned off reminders are better than annoyed users.

posts.cooked:
Mr-Brunes:

other solutions that use a PIN don’t interrupt folks with nagging reminders simply to prevent it from being forgotten, so why is Signal different?

In most cases elsewhere, I think it’s possible to recover your PIN if you forget it. But there is no way to recover your Signal PIN if you forget it (and don’t have an active primary device to change the PIN). From the aforementioned Signal PIN support article:

  • It is important to memorize your PIN. We cannot recover your PIN if you forget it.

But the help article does not say why it is important i.e. make it clear what the impact is of forgetting the PIN.

I read around it some more, having to stop when my head started to hurt, but it seems that if you’ve not lost your device or do not have Registration Lock enabled (disabled by default) then it seems there is no real impact.
" If you do not have a Registration Lock, you can still get started with Signal. Tap SKIP in the top corner."

Screenshot_20210123-211406_Signal720×1520 119 KB

We can see what it says when you dig deeper, UX can be improved by putting the message on the outside. So user does not have to waste time doing research before pressing a button. I have personally experienced something similar to this, I support an improvement.

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
Signal PIN backs up some of your data, like contacts (including whether their safety number is verified or not, their profile key, etc.), groups (so that you don’t have to wait until someone sends a message in it to make it appear), and some settings (your profile (avatar, name, etc.), pinned chats, whether read receipts are enabled or not, etc.).

While you can skip its entry when Registration Lock is disabled, you’ll lose this data. I suppose most of it should be recoverable in most cases currently, but that may change in the future, because (from the Introducing Signal PINs blog post):

As we move to support additional features the Signal community has asked for – like addressing that isn’t based on phone numbers and chatting with contacts that aren’t saved in an address book – it means that more and more of this important supporting data can also be lost.

PINs will also help facilitate new features like addressing that isn’t based exclusively on phone numbers, since the system address book will no longer be a viable way to maintain your network of contacts.
Where’s that screenshot from?

posts.cooked: @Mr-Brunes Signal Settings > Privacy > PIN reminders (the prompt asks to confirm your Signal PIN before disabling reminders).

Tx for the info.
Either way to summarise the original nag mesage should either:

  1. Be removed completely, since it’s fundamentally patronising. Other PIN-using apps (arguably rather more important ones like credit cards) don’t have nag reminders since they know they’d annoy customers.

or

  1. Add links to the option disable reminders and to more info on the impact of forgetting the PIN.

I would also like to show my support for a change, although I think the change could be more efficient and user friendly if it were introduced much earlier, before the user ever sees a single reminder:

Introduce a new dialog right after the user has created their PIN, in which you explain exactly what these reminders are, why they are important, and ask whether the user would like to opt out of these reminders right there and then from that dialog. Then you could tell the user that they can always toggle the reminders on/off or reset their PIN through the app’s privacy settings if they forget their PIN or change their mind about the reminders.

posts.cooked:
Mr-Brunes:

Other PIN-using apps (arguably rather more important ones like credit cards) don’t have nag reminders since they know they’d annoy customers.

I would disagree that this is the reason they don’t have a reminder. Most apps like that have some way that you can “recover” from a lost PIN – by proving you know something that the company already knows about you, eg your SSN or some other personal information. Your PIN in those cases also don’t serve as part of the encryption key for your data, so it can easily be replaced with a new one.

Mr-Brunes:

Add links to the option disable reminders and to more info on the impact of forgetting the PIN.

I think this is the best option – the ability to disable the reminder is there, so there’s no reason to leave it up to the user to assume that it exists and go hunting for it in the settings. Either just straight up show an “ignore” button on the notification, with a “are you sure?” prompt with maybe a bit of explanation, or put a “Learn more” button there that explains a bit more about the reminder and mentions that it can be disabled.

I like the onboarding addition as it gives the opportunity to remove this nag at source. Of course it will only affect new users so it’d still be good to fix the current reminder dialogue.

On the credit card comparison, yes it’s not quite apples to apples, but if you forget your card PIN then in most cases you lose the abilty to use it, and resetting the PIN usually takes time and is a PITA.
At least with the forgetting of the Signal PIN (assuming the primary device isn’t available) it seems that you’ll most likely just lose a few settings and core functionality is not affected. The fundamental point though is that users don’t like nagging.

E2A Even though I searched before adding this thread, I never knew of the open feature request wiki (obvs my searching method is broken somehow) and then I found this long (but useful) discussion:

Please make the Signal PIN reminder optional Feature Requests
That’s true, but I believe that people are responsible enough to think about such things. Please don’t take the responsibility (and freedom of choice) from people. This situation is similar to my bank account, where my bank enforced that the password can’t be stored in the system keyring or the browser keyring (by using some dirty hacks), and in this way I had to use weaker password instead of my 16-32 random hash string (and I can’t change it from time to time), which also made…

It got closed with the addition of the buried disable PIN reminder option.

posts.name: Don
posts.cooked:
I understand people being annoyed by the “nag” message and I agree that people should be able to disable or remove it if they wish.

But before anyone actually disables or removes the “nag” message, there is a VERY BIG QUESTION that needs to be considered: Are you CERTAIN have your Signal Pin recorded somewhere where you can find it if you ever need it or are you CERTAIN that you will never forget your Signal PIN?

Remember, PIN was created so that, if you ever need to install Signal on a new or different device, you can access your existing Signal account by using your PIN. IF you lose or forget your PIN then you lose access to your existing Signal account. For some people this could be a big problem. If you are not CERTAIN about your PIN then maybe these “nag” messages might not be so bad.

This is (or should be) an individual decision that every user should be able to make for themselves and should be made CAREFULLY!
In case you don’t know, you can reset the pin without knowing the old pin. You just need access to the app and you should still be registered.
